problem.tex: Let $\Omega$ be a bounded domain. Let $a\in\Omega$ and define $L_a:L^2(\Omega)\to\mathbb{C}$ be $L_a(f)=f(a)$. We know $L_a$ is a bounded operator. By the Riesz representation theorem, there is an $L^2$ holomorphic function $R_a$ for each $a$ such that \[L_a(f)=\langle f,R_a\rangle.\] Define the Bergman kernel function $K:\Omega\times\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$ as $K(z,w)=\overline{R_z(w)}$. Show that $K$ is holomorphic in $z$, antiholomorphic in $w$, and that for each $f\in L^2(\Omega)$ and $z\in\Omega$, \[f(z)=\iint_\Omega f(x+iy)K(z,x+iy)dxdy.\]

solution.tex: We show the formula first. We know $f(z)=\langle f,R_z\rangle$, so \[f(z)=\iint_\Omega f(x+iy)\overline{R_z(x+iy)}dxdy.\] This is exactly the required formula. Now to show $K$ is conjugate symmetric. \[R_z(w)=\iint_\Omega R_z(x+iy)\overline{R_w(x+iy)}dxdy=\overline{\iint_\Omega R_w(x+iy)\overline{R_z(x+iy)}dxdy}=\overline{R_w(z)}\] We show $K$ is holomorphic in $z$, antiholomorphic in $w$ follows from conjugate symmetry. Fix $z,w\in\Omega$. Then \[\lim_{h\to0}\frac{1}{h}(K(z+h,w)-K(z,w))=\lim_{h\to0}\frac{1}{h}\overline{\left(R_{z+h}(w)-R_z(w)\right)}\] \[=\lim_{h\to0}\frac{1}{h}\left(R_w(z+h)-R_w(z)\right).\] Recall $R_w\in L^2(\Omega)$, so $R_w$ is holomorphic and this limit converges to its derivative. Thus $K(z,w)$ is holomorphic in $z$.
